javaslang

Interface ValueObject

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Serializable
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    BinaryTree<T>, CheckResult, Either<L,R>, List<T>, Option<T>, RoseTree<T>, RoseTree.NonNil<T>, Stream<T>, Tree<T>, Try<T>, Tuple
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    BinaryTree.AbstractBinaryTree, BinaryTree.Branch, BinaryTree.Leaf, BinaryTree.Nil, CheckResult.Erroneous, CheckResult.Falsified, CheckResult.Satisfied, Failure, Failure.Cause, Failure.Fatal, Failure.NonFatal, Lazy, Left, List.AbstractList, List.Cons, List.Nil, None, Right, RoseTree.AbstractRoseTree, RoseTree.Branch, RoseTree.Leaf, RoseTree.Nil, Some, Stream.AbstractStream, Stream.Cons, Stream.Nil, Success, Tuple0, Tuple1, Tuple10, Tuple11, Tuple12, Tuple13, Tuple14, Tuple15, Tuple16, Tuple17, Tuple18, Tuple19, Tuple2, Tuple20, Tuple21, Tuple22, Tuple23, Tuple24, Tuple25, Tuple26, Tuple3, Tuple4, Tuple5, Tuple6, Tuple7, Tuple8, Tuple9

    public interface ValueObject
extends Serializable

    Value Objects are immutable, decomposable objects with an identity based on their type and encapsulated values.

    In particular the identity of a Value Object should be defined by its content by implementing Object.equals(Object), Object.hashCode() and Object.toString() appropriately.

    The unapply() method decomposes an Object by unwrapping it. This comes handy when using the Match API.

    Please note that a Value Object is not cloneable because of the following conclusion:
    "[...] , it doesn’t make sense for immutable classes to support object copying, because copies would be virtually indistinguishable from the original."
    (see Effective Java, 2nd ed., p. 61).
    Since:
    1.1.0

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      boolean equals(Object o)
      Checks if o equals this.
      int hashCode()

      String toString()
      Returns a String representation of this object including type and state.
      Tuple unapply()
      Decomposes this object into its parts.

    • Method Detail

      • unapply

        Tuple unapply()
        Decomposes this object into its parts.
        Returns:
        a Tuple of parts of the construction of this object.

      • equals

        boolean equals(Object o)
        Checks if o equals this. 
             
     if (o == this) {
         return true;
     } else if (o instanceof CurrentType) {
         final CurrentType that = (CurrentType) o;
         return ...; // check if values of this and that are pairwise equal
     } else {
         return false;
     }
        Please note that double and float values 0.0 and -0.0 are considered to be not equal when using Double.compare(double, double), just in case.
        Overrides:
        equals in class Object
        Parameters:
        o - An object, may be null.
        Returns:
        true, if o equals this, false otherwise.
        See Also:
        Objects.equals(Object, Object)
